article: One rainy evening I went to fill up at the gas station. A pre-teen boy approached my car with a thick hoodie 21 _ around his face. He asked me for money to help him and his mother stay in their hotel for an additional week. He stated that if they did not22 come up with $25 they would be driven out that23 _ evening. Having worked in social services before, and being a little skeptical, I asked how come his mother hadn't sought out social services for24 _ . The boy said that they needed to25 _ in their hotel for one more week until his grandmother, who lived out of town, could take them in. I gave the boy what I had -- $5. He thanked me and continued to26 _ the parking lot asking for help. I got my gas and drove away. A(n)27 _ time some weeks ago, a boy asked me for money and I told him I didn't have any28 _ I did. The skeptic in me had29 _ out. Yet, I thought about it, felt30 _ at my skepticism and went31 looking for the boy to give him a dollar. But it seemed that he had disappeared into thin air."This time,"I thought,"I'll do it32 _ ." I reached into my33 _ and took out an additional $20; then I returned to the gas station. The boy was34 _ there. I observed him35 _ approaching strangers who walked past him but took no36 _ of him. I pulled up beside a pump and waved37 _ the boy to come over. I handed him the $20 bill. He38 _ through my car window and gave me a huge hug. His hug told me all I needed to know -- that finally this kid could get out of the39 _ , the cold and the darkening sky and go inside where it was40 _ .
